awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a 400 MHz Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) Spectrometer to Support Undergraduate Research at High Point University
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Instrumentation Programs. Professor Pamela Lundin from High Point University and colleagues Andrew Wommack, Melissa Srougi and Meghan Blackledge are acquiring a 400 MHz Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectrometer that replaced an older low-field spectrometer. In general, NMR spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists to determine of the structure of molecules. NMR spectroscopy is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solution or in the solid state. Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is essential to chemists who are carrying out frontier research. The NMR studies improve understanding of synthetic organic/inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry. This instrument is an integral part of teaching as well as research performed by undergraduate and graduate students and several early career faculty  members at this growing institution. While using the instrument, students gain essential analytical skills that allow them to become more competitive candidates for industrial careers and graduate school programs. In addition, the NMR spectrometer is incorporated into the evolving portfolio of instrumentation utilized by this institution's Mobile Community Laboratory.  NMR is used to illustrate the concepts of structural chemistry and kinetics to local middle and high school students and to expand participation in STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) programs.

The award of the NMR spectrometer is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. It especially impacts the characterization of polymerization products such as those of poly(3-hexylthiophene) and poly(phenylene ethynylenes) and the use of thiol-ene coupling reactions to generate redox-inert disulfide bioisosteres. The instrumentation also serves researchers elucidating the mechanism of antidepresant-dibenzazepine inhibition of protein serine/threonine (Stk1) kinase, and those designing, synthesizing and characterizing quinone structures. These research projects benefit the National health and welfare as well as education and diversity efforts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is arguably one of the most important techniques available to synthetic chemists to determine molecular structure. This grant supported the acquisition of a JEOL 400 MHz nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectrometer at High Point University (HPU), which has had a transformational impact on the training of undergraduate students in laboratory courses and in research projects as HPU has not previously had a research grade NMR spectrometer on campus available for undergraduate student use. The instrument was installed in its own laboratory space in the brand new Wanek School of Natural Sciences building. The NMR Laboratory is down the hall from both the Organic Chemistry Teaching Laboratory and the Synthetic Research Laboratory, facilitating its routine use. The acquisition of the NMR spectrometer was a key final piece that allowed the HPU Department of Chemistry to receive certification of its B.S. Chemistry major by the American Chemical Society.

Hands-on use of the NMR spectrometer has been incorporated into six undergraduate courses and has been used by over 300 undergraduate students over the course of the three-year grant period. Organic Chemistry II Laboratory students (~100/year) use the NMR spectrometer to confirm the structure of their synthetic products in three different multi-week experiments. In Majors Organic Chemistry II Laboratory (~15/year), the students have used the NMR for product confirmation in a multi-step synthesis laboratory experiment in which they synthesized the COVID-19 antiviral drug molnupiravir and in a polymerization experiment in which they propose and execute an experimental polystyrene synthesis. Our majors are re-exposed to use of the NMR spectrometer in upper-level courses such as Quantitative Analysis, Drug Discovery and Nanoscience in which they learn more sophisticated 2D NMR techniques to quantify the amount of vitamin D in different apple varieties, for example, or to determine the critical micelle concentration of novel amphiphilic molecules. NMR spectroscopy has also been introduced to non-STEM majors through a honors scientific reasoning course ?How Molecules Shape Experience?; in course evaluations, students mentioned the use of modern analytical instrumentation as one of the highlights of the course.

The acquisition of the NMR spectrometer has had an even bigger impact on the undergraduate research programs at HPU. Previously, faculty had to drive approximately 30 minutes to run student NMR samples at nearby institutions. Students are now able to run their own samples and within a few minutes use that data to inform the next steps of their research projects, considerably expediting research progress. To date, peer-review publications on the synthesis of a novel dimer of the dye rhodamine B and on the identification and evaluation of brominated carbazoles for repotentiation of antibiotics against antibiotic resistant bacterial strains have been published, and more manuscripts for peer-reviewed publication are in process. Results of these projects and others have also been disseminated in presentations at scientific conferences. The NMR has also been used by faculty in High Point University?s Fred Wilson School of Pharmacy for their research programs, and by scientists at the High Point location of Kao Specialties America which has strengthened this academic-industry partnership between our institutions.

High Point University?s Community Mobile Laboratory has partnered with the Department of Chemistry to bring NMR-related scientific demonstrations to the broader community through scientific outreach events. Additionally, the glass wall of the NMR Laboratory facilitates the NMR being a frequent stop on tours of our new building, and it has been used for outreach with high school students who are on-campus for other educational events.

Modified by: Pamela Lundin
